output: The ‘toss’ is the ‘news’ story pitched onto the Internet and picked up by mainstream media. Of course, if a player has the funds, he or she can publish a whole bogus newspaper or political poster allegedly ascribed to the rival party and designed to make the rival look like an anti-Semite, a raging nationalist or hard-core Communist. ‘Clones’ are politicians who are hired to take up the campaign promises of a rival in order to steal vote. ‘Clones’ differ from ‘doubles,’ who are candidates that run with nearly the same name as a rival so as to confuse voters, ‘Administrative resources’ describes a range of activities in a politician’s toolkit, from ballot-stuffing, selective taxation and prosecution, and just plain threats employed to command local bureaucrats to get out and/or obstruct the vote.

instruction: Given a sentence in Tagalog language, translate the sentence to English language keeping the meaning of the original sentence intact.
input: Tagalog sentence: Doon, sa kanyang mga libro sa paligid sa kanya, sa kanyang mga talahanayan sakop sa kalinisan disorder sa hindi mabilang mga scraps ng mga materyales at kasangkapan na gagamitin bilang dynamical mga modelo, ang kanyang mga dingding festooned sa bawat pagkakaiba-iba ng mga palawit, simpleng o tambalang, contrived na binili mula sa mga artikulo sa ilalim ng isang limitasyon ng inireseta ng gastos sa mga lokal na tindahan, sa kanyang mga sahig ang treasured roll ng Turkish karpet mula sa kanyang kuwarto ng matagal na ang nakalipas at St John's, at sa ibabaw ng mantelpiece ang larawan ng kanyang minamahal guro, Clerk Maxwell, smiling approval - sa lahat ng mga ito at ang pinakamamahal alaala na sila alaala, ang mga iskolar ay nilalaman.
output: There, with his books around him, his tables covered in neat disorder with innumerable scraps of material and apparatus to be used as dynamical models, his walls festooned with every variety of pendulum, simple or compound, contrived from articles purchased below a prescribed limit of cost at the local stores, upon his floor the treasured roll of Turkish carpet from his room of long ago at St John's, and above the mantelpiece the portrait of his beloved teacher, Clerk Maxwell, smiling approval - with all these and the precious memories they recalled, the scholar was content.
